title: Visual Arts
description: A progressive journey through the core elements, principles, mediums, history, and theories of the visual arts.

paragraphs.summary: An introduction to visual arts as a broad category of art forms that create works primarily visual in nature, such as drawing, painting, sculpture, and photography.
Exploring the diverse functions of art, including self-expression, communication of ideas, social commentary, aesthetic pleasure, and ritualistic or symbolic purposes.
Developing the ability to carefully observe and perceive visual details, relationships, and nuances in the world, crucial for artistic representation.
Understanding line as a fundamental visual element defined by a point moving in space; exploring its types (straight, curved, implied) and qualities (thick, thin, broken).
Defining shape as a two-dimensional area enclosed by lines or defined by changes in color or value; categorizing shapes (geometric, organic).
Understanding form as a three-dimensional object possessing height, width, and depth, or the illusion of three-dimensionality on a 2D surface.
Exploring space as the area around, between, or within components of a piece; includes positive and negative space, and creating depth.
The perceived surface quality of a work of art, which can be actual (tactile, physical) or implied (visual).
The lightness or darkness of tones or colors. White is the lightest value; black is the darkest. Value creates contrast and form.
Introduction to the fundamental properties of color: hue (the pure color), value (lightness/darkness), and saturation (intensity/purity).
A circular diagram illustrating relationships between primary, secondary, and tertiary colors.
Principles for combining colors in visually pleasing ways, such as complementary, analogous, triadic, and monochromatic schemes.
The organization and arrangement of visual elements (line, shape, color, etc.) within a work of art according to principles of design.
The distribution of visual weight in a composition, which can be symmetrical, asymmetrical, or radial.
The arrangement of opposite elements (light vs. dark, rough vs. smooth, large vs. small) to create visual interest or excitement.
Creating a center of interest or focal point in a work of art that draws the viewer's attention.
The use of recurring elements to create a sense of rhythm, or visual pathways that direct the viewer's eye through the artwork.
The regular repetition of lines, shapes, colors, or motifs to create pattern and visual structure.
Creating a sense of cohesion and completeness in a work of art, where all elements work together harmoniously.
Proportion refers to the relative size and scale of the various elements in a design. Scale refers to the size of an object in relation to another object.
Techniques used to represent three-dimensional objects and space on a two-dimensional surface, such as linear and atmospheric perspective.
Overview of common materials used for drawing, including graphite pencils, charcoal, conte crayons, ink (pen and brush), and pastels.
A drawing technique focused on capturing the outlines and essential edges of a subject, defining its form and volume.
Quick, expressive drawings that capture the essential movement, action, and form of a subject, often a figure.
Methods used to create the illusion of light, shadow, and form, such as hatching, cross-hatching, stippling, and blending.
Overview of common painting mediums, including watercolor, gouache, acrylics, and oil paints, and their distinct characteristics.
The characteristic way an artist applies paint with a brush, influencing texture, form, and expressive quality.
Common materials used in sculpture, including clay (modeling), stone and wood (carving), metal (casting, welding), and found objects (assemblage).
Sculptural processes where material is added to build up the form, such as modeling with clay or assemblage.
Sculptural processes where material is removed from a larger block to reveal the form, primarily carving in wood or stone.
The artistic process of creating artworks by printing, normally on paper, from a prepared plate or block, allowing for multiple originals.
Printmaking techniques (e.g., woodcut, linocut) where the image is printed from the raised areas of a carved block.
Printmaking techniques (e.g., engraving, etching) where the image is incised into a surface, and the incised line or sunken area holds the ink.
Fundamental principles of photography, including camera operation (aperture, shutter speed, ISO), lighting, and composition.
Artistic work or practice that uses digital technologies as an essential part of the creative or presentation process.
Artworks composed from a combination of different materials and media.
Overview of art from ancient civilizations, including Egyptian, Greek, and Roman periods, focusing on key styles and iconic works.
The period of European history marking the transition from the Middle Ages to modernity, characterized by a revival of classical learning and art.
A 19th-century art movement characterized by relatively small, thin, yet visible brush strokes, open composition, emphasis on accurate depiction of light and its changing qualities.
A broad movement in Western art, architecture and design which flouted traditional styles, encompassing Cubism, Fauvism, Surrealism, Abstract Expressionism, etc.
Art produced in the present day or recent past, characterized by its global nature, diversity of materials, forms, and concepts.
A branch of philosophy dealing with the nature of beauty, art, and taste, and with the creation and appreciation of beauty.
The discussion or evaluation of visual art, often involving interpretation of meaning, analysis of form, and judgment of quality.

The branch of art history which studies the identification, description, and the interpretation of the content of images: the subjects depicted, the particular compositions and details used to do so, and other elements that are distinct from artistic style.
The study of signs and symbols and their interpretation, applied to visual art to understand how meaning is constructed and communicated.
Examining the relationship between art and its cultural context, including how art reflects and shapes societal values, beliefs, and identities.
Exploring how art can be used as a form of political expression, social critique, propaganda, or activism.
Understanding the economic systems surrounding the creation, buying, selling, and valuation of art, including galleries, auctions, and collectors.
The profession devoted to the preservation of cultural heritage for the future, involving examination, documentation, treatment, and preventative care.
The process of an artist cultivating a distinctive and recognizable manner of creating art, reflecting their unique vision, techniques, and influences.
The process of giving and receiving constructive feedback on artworks to foster growth, understanding, and refinement.
Curating a collection of an artist's best work to showcase their skills, style, and artistic development for academic or professional purposes.
